chunk: okay so in today's Q&A with Milo we have a question from Jack and Jack asks how

make sure that you're taking away by turning your chest to begin the swing your hands really don't engage until the
button to the club gets out even with your right leg because if we if we don't engage it by turning first for many of
you you'll never get turned so you're back smooth but I see a lot of us arms moving first and shoulders not really turning
and that really throws a wrench into the sequencing on the downswing because you're your brain tries to find power somewhere and you wind up jumping and
throwing the club and that you see a lot of of the standing up and the club coming in steep because of that so I
want you to make sure you really turn first before you engage and start letting your wrist hinge now your wrists are going to start to hinge about the time the butt of the club gets even with

control how far back you take well the transition dictates how long the backswing is so if if you turn and you

if if your tendency is to go too far what you need to focus on rather than trying to shorten your backswing try to make your transition happen earlier so you're going to feel like you're making

parallel there's no way the club's getting over here so some things to look
for I want you to make sure your arm swing and your shoulder turn are stopping about the same time if your
shoulders have stopped turning and your arms keep swinging it's going to be really tough for you to sequence it up so you want to make sure that when you
